name: Configurable Notification and Nudging
description: This use case enables older adults and caregivers to customize notification preferences and behavioral nudging settings in ALFRED, balancing timely health interventions with minimizing distractions during critical care moments.
scenario:
Elena Rivera woke up eager to start her day, energized by the challenges ALFRED suggested overnight. She had configured the system to nudge her continuously with health reminders and exercise prompts, welcoming every alert as a push toward better wellbeing. “ALFRED, remind me again to drink water every hour,” she requested cheerfully, appreciating the assistant’s insistence. She even opted into spontaneous video check-ins, seeing them as an opportunity to connect with her medical team and family without barriers.

Meanwhile, Mike Johnson, the registered nurse responsible for monitoring Elena’s health during his busy hospital shifts, logged into ALFRED’s caregiver dashboard. His priority was efficiency—he needed to access vital data quickly without interruptions. He frowned as he saw the flood of notifications from Elena’s device, many of which he considered non-critical. Mike had configured his ALFRED interface to block all non-emergency alerts during work hours, but Elena’s settings pushed through reminders and social nudges that distracted him. He wished the system would force patients like Elena to wear sensors and accept only clinically relevant notifications, eliminating what he saw as “noise.”

Later that afternoon, Mike attempted to adjust Elena’s notification preferences remotely, aiming to silence non-urgent prompts while keeping critical health alerts active. Elena, happily exploring ALFRED’s voice commands, overheard the change and immediately voiced her disagreement: “ALFRED, tell Mike I want to keep all my reminders and nudges active—I need the motivation!” She relished the system’s detailed explanations and wanted to learn every feature. Mike, however, was frustrated that he could not override her settings entirely, especially since he preferred to limit distractions during his visits and clinical interactions.

Their conflicting priorities became evident when Mike scheduled a video check-in, only to find Elena already engaged in an exercise simulation she had chosen herself. Mike disliked these non-clinical activities and felt they wasted valuable time. Elena, on the other hand, embraced the hard challenges ALFRED offered, thriving on the system’s encouragement. When Mike suggested reducing such activities to focus solely on medical monitoring, Elena insisted on retaining autonomy over her daily routine, even if it meant receiving more notifications than Mike found convenient.

In the end, ALFRED served as an uneasy mediator: it respected Elena’s desire for full engagement with the system’s features and open data sharing, while also providing Mike tools to filter alerts during his work hours. Though their preferences clashed, both recognized the system’s flexibility allowed them to coexist—Elena empowered by constant nudging and learning, Mike by quieting distractions and focusing on clinical essentials. Yet beneath this fragile balance lay the persistent tension between care efficiency and patient autonomy, made tangible every time ALFRED spoke.
